tasks.task: Addressing issues with fig tree fruiting through proper pruning techniques.
subtasks: Identifying the common cause of fig trees not fruiting (hormonal imbalances rather than water, health, sunlight, or fertilizer issues).
Highlighting the role of hormones in fruiting plants and the importance of pruning timing.
Demonstrating summer pruning technique for cherry trees by removing a third to half of new growth to encourage flowering and fruiting the following year.
Explaining the specific pruning needs of fig trees, which produce fruit on new seasonal growth and cannot have new growth removed during summer.
Advising winter pruning for fig trees to control height and manage hormonal balance, recommending thinning cuts rather than heading cuts to prevent hormonal imbalances leading to reduced fruiting.
Demonstrating thinning cut pruning technique for fig trees, focusing on removal of one of the longest trunks from the base to encourage new growth.
Discussing the potential for successful fruiting by protecting fig trees from winter damage and allowing them to recover through proper seasoning.
Encouraging patient management and appropriate pruning methods for ensuring fig trees fruit.
